required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Carpal Tunnel Release Effects on Median Nerve Perfusion
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Carpal Tunnel Release on Median Nerve Perfusion Using SPY Scope Imaging

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to examine the effect of carpal tunnel release on blood flow to the median nerve using SPY scope imaging to view the perfusion to the nerve.

detailed_description.textblock: The study will involve patients undergoing carpal tunnel release surgery at our institution, with no change in the actual procedure performed. Using the SPY Scope, we will measure blood flow prior to the carpal tunnel release, and again measure once carpal tunnel release has been performed, in order to compare the values. This may add roughly 15 minutes to the total procedure time, however, no steps in the actual operation will be altered or affected in any way.

clinical_study.why_stopped: never initiated; did not recruit patients

primary_outcome.measure: Effect of median nerve perfusion with carpal tunnel release
primary_outcome.description: This study aims to examine the effect of carpal tunnel release on blood flow to the median nerve using SPY scope imaging.

arm_group.description: Injection of indigocyanine green dye to evaluate perfusion of the median nerve with the SPY scope before and after carpal tunnel release

intervention.description: Each patient will receive 1 injection of indigocyanine green dye using 2.5 mg/mL concentration of the imaging agent. 3mL of this mixture will be injected intravenously, followed by 10mL NS bolus, just prior to imaging with the SPY scope

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- carpal tunnel syndrome
- 18 years or older
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnant
- less than 18 years of age
- allergy to iodide or iodinated contrast agents
